data.title: Silvio Berlusconi latest: 'Many loved him, many hated him' - reaction as scandal-hit former Italian PM dies
data.meta_description: Once the 12th richest man in the world, the former Italian prime minister was a controversial figure, with sex scandals, tax fraud allegations and confidence votes tainting his vast career. Follow all the reaction here after his death at the age of 86.
data.text:
Berlusconi has spent much of the past 30 years embroiled in legal battles. In all, he faced 35 criminal court cases, but only one conviction.

'Ruby' cases

Berlusconi was accused of abuse of office and paying for sex

in 2010 with a minor, nightclub dancer Karima El Mahroug, better known in Italy by her stage name, Ruby the Heartstealer.

Berlusconi was initially found guilty in 2013 and sentenced

to seven years in jail, before an appeals court found there was no proof he had known that she was 17 and Italy's top court confirmed his acquittal in 2015.

He was back in the dock after being accused of bribing witnesses to lie in the original Ruby trial, before being cleared again.

Conviction

The only Berlusconi trial that ended with a final conviction

was one for tax fraud, false accounting and embezzlement tied to

his media empire, then called Mediaset.

In 2013, the top court confirmed Berlusconi's sentence of four years' imprisonment, three of which were covered by a pardon. He completed his sentence as community service from 2014 to 2015.

Acquittals

A total of 10 cases ended with an acquittal.

Statute of limitations and amnesties

A further 10 trials concluded with a decision not to pursue the case, many because the statute of limitations came into force.

This included a case where Berlusconi was originally found guilty of bribing a senator in 2006 to bring down the then centre-left government.

Dropped cases

Another 10 proceedings ended with a preliminary judge deciding to drop the case without going to trial.

Mired in a sex scandal, Silvio Berlusconi held a dinner party at a posh Rome hotel in 2010 to charm reporters - but struggled to play it straight: "You're all invited to the bunga bunga!" he told us defiantly.

Then the impish smile. "But you'd be disappointed."

When it came to entertainment, Berlusconi - the media mogul-turned-prime minister, his hair slicked back and face orange from a fake tan - rarely disappointed. When it came to governing, he disappointed many parts of his country.

Yet upon leaving office a year after that dinner, never to return to power, the Milanese magnate left behind an enduring political legacy - and leadership vacuum - that affects Italy more than a decade later.

Read the full analysis by Alessandra Rizzo here...

"Gone is the great fighter. Rest in peace, my friend," said Viktor Orban, the Hungarian prime minister.

Roberto Mancini, head coach of the Italian national team, said Berlusconi's death "is a great regret, I think it is for everyone because he was an extraordinary man for sport, also for politics, so today is a very sad day".

He was quoted by our Italian partner network, Sky tg24.

Roberto Calderoli, regional affairs minister, said:

"Today I mourn Silvio, a friend of many moments, of many years together, of many laughs and also of many difficult moments.

"Today I remember my friend Silvio, I mourn my friend, with a prayer that I know he would appreciate, sending a big hug to his large family, to his children, to all those who loved him like me."

Tributes are flooding in for the three-time prime minister.

His death leaves a "huge void" because he was a great man, Italian defence minister Guido Crosetto said.

"I loved him very much. Farewell Silvio."

Senator Matthew Renzi said: "Silvio Berlusconi made history in this country. Many loved him, many hated him: today everyone must recognise that his impact on political life but also on economics, sports and television was unprecedented.

"Today Italy mourns together to the family, to his loved ones, to his companies, to his party. We will miss you Pres, may the earth be light on you."
